qas.question: What is often included in an eclectic reading?

answers.text: an impression of the number of witnesses

qas.question: Why would someone prefer a second edition to a first edition?

answers.text: a second edition of a Shakespeare play may include an addition alluding to an event known to have happened between the two editions

qas.question: Do textual critics always include additions found in the majority of subsequent versions of a work?

answers.text: textual critics may reconstruct the original without the addition.

plausible_answers.text: impression of the number of witnesses

qas.question: What do eclectic readings not do?

plausible_answers.text: may include an addition alluding to an event known to have happened between the two editions

qas.question: Why do people prefer a first edition Shakespeare play?
Which edition did not include an addition alluding to an event?
Textual critics may reconstruct the last edition of a work without what?

context: Eclectic readings also normally give <a0_0>an <b3_0>impression of the number of witnesses<b3_0/><a0_0/> to each available reading. Although a reading supported by the majority of witnesses is frequently preferred, this does not follow automatically. For example, <a1_0>a <b5_0>second<b5_0/> edition of a Shakespeare play <b4_0>may include an addition alluding to an event known to have happened between the two editions<b4_0/><a1_0/>. Although nearly all subsequent manuscripts may have included the addition, <a2_0>textual critics may reconstruct the original without <b6_0>the addition<b6_0/>.
